[Godzilla Threshold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodzillaThreshold): With the Diamond Weapons tearing Insomnia apart, the treacherous Glaives killing the loyalists, and himself on the brink of death from gunshot wounds with Glauca charging forward to murder him and Lunafreya, Nyx wields the Ring of the Lucii. While the kings believe that a commoner such as him is unworthy, the newest king, Regis vouches for him, calling him an outstanding warrior. It isn't until Nyx openly laughs at the kings and calls them out on their cowardice that they grant him the power of kings. Of course, the price of the pact is a [heavy one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice).
[Hearing Voices](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HearingVoices): Hears his dead sister's voice calling out to him in the past several times in battle, causing him to lose his focus.

[The Hero Dies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeroDies): He's unquestionably the main protagonist of the film. And he dies at the end due to his use of the Ring of the Lucii to hold off Glauca and Niflheim from Insomnia.
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): He's clearly devastated when Crowe is killed.

[Heroic RRoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicRROD): At the end of *Kingsglaive*, Nyx uses the Ring of the Lucii's powers to fight Glauca. It greatly shortens his lifespan to the point that he eventually dies from the effort after defeating Glauca.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Gives up his life in order to allow Luna to escape with the Ring of the Lucii, ultimately playing a major role in saving the entire world, ensuring the defeat of the Empire and ending the Starscourge by making sure it gets to Noctis.
[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): Specifically, of *Kingsglaive*'s, since he is unheard of in the game  (SPOILER) aside from a brief cameo as a corpse .

[Humble Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumbleHero): One look at his flat is all that's needed to spell out "below the poverty line." Yet as a member of the Kingsglaive, an elite unit handpicked by King Regis himself to receive his power, he most likely *has* the means to live if not an affluent lifestyle, at least one in the comfortable middle-class, yet he chooses not to.
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): Especially noticeable when compared to [Prince Noctis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrettyBoy) of the two FFXV protagonists.
[In-Series Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InSeriesNickname): A relatively understated one, but Nyx is constantly called "Hero" by the other Kingsglaive members.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Nyx may have an arrogant personality, but he is a good person.

[Kukris Are Kool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KukrisAreKool) : Nyx's weapons of choice are a [pair of kukris](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding), used in conjunction with his warping. These same knives can be obtained in *Final Fantasy XV* as weapons for Noctis or Ignis.

[The Last Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLastDance): At the end of *Kingsglaive*, he uses the Ring of the Lucii's powers to launch a [Final Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBattle) with General Glauca.
[Light Liege, Dark Defender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightLiegeDarkDefender): The dark defender to Lunafreya's light liege.
[Man on Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOnFire): Towards the end of the film, he combusts twice as a result due to the Ring of the Lucii's powers greatly shortening his lifespan.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Nyx was the goddess of the night. When the night goes away, [so does he](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeroDies). Ulric is a variant of the German names Ulrich ("heritage ruler") and Wulfric ("wolf ruler").
[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): His mother likely died when his hometown was invaded.
[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice): Much like Gladio before him, his [Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk) status is shown off through promotional pinups showing off his bod.
[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure): Failing to protect his mother and sister from the imperial army when they invaded his hometown.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): He is utterly shocked when he realizes that Pelna is going to fall into a trap by the imperials while the latter rescues Luna and when he sees Regis being [Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice) at Glauca's hands.
[One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy): As the Lucis invasion force of Niflheim and Glauca ended up learning the hard way.
[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): Like Gladio and Cor, that's his job.

[Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter): In the game proper - also counts as a [Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter) since his actions are the only reason Noctis and the bros get as far as they do. In Comrades, he's regarded with legendary status as the best of the Glaives, and his friendship with Libertus is highlighted in random notes and letters.

[Power at a Price](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerAtAPrice): After making a contract with the previous kings of Lucis to stop Glauca despite not being of the royal bloodline, Nyx is only granted until dawn to use the ring's power. When dawn does arrive, his body slowly starts to disintegrate.

[Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica): For disobeying orders to retreat during the opening battle, he temporarily gets assigned to gatekeeping, with the other gatekeepers mocking him for being an immigrant. Following the news that Regis agreed to Niflheim's unilateral peace treaty, however, Drautos personally assigns him to the Crownsguard.
[Religious and Mythological Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousAndMythologicalThemeNaming): Nyx was the Greek primordial goddess of the night.
[Scarf of Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarfOfAsskicking): Unlike the other glaives, he attaches a blue scarf to his uniform.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): Downplayed, but seems to share this with her in his time [protecting Lunafreya](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardCrush).

[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): During the finale of *Kingsglaive*:
QUOTE **Glauca:** A man's past is his pride. 
**Nyx:** No. My pride is shaping the future.

[Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): To the Empire's scheme to destroy Lucis and steal the crystal and the ring. While they manage to devastate Insomnia and get the crystal, [thanks to Glauca's manipulations](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobFixingItVillain) for Nyx to be in the position to protect Lunafreya, he ends up doing his job a little too well, gaining the power of the ring and ensuring it and Lunafreya escape the city, while he takes down Glauca and prevents the Empire from destroying Insomnia entirely, destroying or repulsing their entire invasion force.

[Supporting Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingProtagonist): [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) to Prince Noctis's [The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne), both of their actions and sacrifices saving the world.

[Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption): The spirits of the Kings of Lucis attempt to force a [Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice) on Nyx, that he must choose whether Libertus or Lunafreya will die in exchange for their power. He tells them all to go to hell instead, shaming them for their refusal to intervene and protect Insomnia against Niflheim's invasion. With King Regis' spirit vouching for him and his worthiness, it works, though he takes the cost on to himself, trading his life for theirs.
[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): One of the few members of the Kingsglaive unit who *isn't* a traitor.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To King Regis, to whom he owes a [Life Debt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LifeDebt).
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Of Glauca's, though he manages to turn the tables on the traitor by the end.
[You Shall Not Pass!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShallNotPass): He launches a final assault on Glauca to allow Libertus and Luna to escape.

[Acrofatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Acrofatic): He's noticeably plump, but not in a "couch potato overweight" sort of way - he's got more of a "retired football player" physique. And he's *just* as physically capable and nimble as any other Glaive.
[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): Towards Crowe since they were kids.
[Big Fun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFun): He has a large physique and is a cheerful individual.

[The Bus Came Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBusCameBack): After a complete absence from the main campaign of *Final Fantasy XV*, Libertus returns as an occasional mentor and ally to the player character in *Comrades*, the multiplayer expansion.

[Car Fu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarFu): In order to confirm his suspicions after overhearing communications from various sides of the conflict, he tries to run Drautos over with Noct's [Audi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProductPlacement), forcing Drautos to [reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal) [himself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstantArmor) as Glauca.
[Childhood Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriends): With Nyx and Crowe.

[Functional Addict](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunctionalAddict): He's addicted to painkillers due to his injury, but it's never shown to compromise his faculties. He finally tosses his pills away near the end when he's asked to protect Luna.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): During a couple of scripted events in *Comrades*, he is an AI controlled party member.  (SPOILER) Including in the final battle against Bahamut.

[Handicapped Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandicappedBadass): His left leg is crushed by a rock during the opening battle, and he spends the entirety of the movie in a cast. Doesn't stop him from being able to drive Lunafreya through the chaos of Insomnia's invasion, and even try to run over [Glauca](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan) twice. The leg injury has healed by the time of *Comrades*, however.
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): Libertus has a major one when Crowe is killed, which leads to his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn).

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): Near the end of the film, he realizes that Niflheim was pulling the strings behind his resistance cell and rejoins Nyx's side, helping Luna escape Insomnia while Nyx battles General Glauca.

[Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded): Fairly impulsive and boorish, he reacts angrily to Lucis's decision to make peace with Niflheim, and is just as pissed when Luche flat out tells him Lucis is screwed whether or not they agree to it.
[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): His likeness is based on his English voice actor, Liam Mulvey.
[Insignia Rip-Off Ritual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsigniaRipOffRitual): Does this when deserting the Kingsglaive.

[I Will Wait for You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWillWaitForYou): Platonically to Nyx at the end of the movie, saying he will wait for Nyx to come back to their hometown. Tragically, Nyx dies not long after.

[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): By the end of the film, Libertus is the sole remaining Glaive. Averted in *Comrades*, when it's revealed there's a couple more who survived - including the player character. From there on, he and Cor re-form the Glaives with new members.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): His name is derived from *Libertas* (Latin for "liberty"), the Roman goddess and embodiment of liberty. He is a member of the Kingsglaive that fights and protects Lucis and its people from tyranny.

tropeName: Not What I Signed Up For
tropeNotes: [Not What I Signed Up For](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotWhatISignedUpFor): Feeling betrayed by the King, Libertus joins a resistance cell. Once he realizes that the "resistance" is actually working with Niflheim, he pulls his [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn).

[Ooh, Me Accent's Slipping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OohMeAccentsSlipping): His actor's natural Welsh accent tends to slip through every now and again, sometimes to a downright distracting degree. He goes full-blown [Not Even Bothering with the Accent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotEvenBotheringWithTheAccent) in *Comrades*. It's considerably less distracting since it's now consistent.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): Does this twice: first, feeling betrayed by the King, he deserts the Kingsglaive and joins a resistance cell; second, he quits the resistance cell upon learning that they're in bed with Niflheim.
[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): He is the only glaive to survive Niflheim's assault on Insomnia.

[Turncoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Turncoat): Upon learning that Crowe died and convinced that Lucis's stance towards the peace treaty is responsible for it, Libertus decides to abandon the Kingsglaive and joins a civilian resistance cell composed of similarly-minded, anti-treaty militants.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): A key player during the events of the movie, yet he's nowhere to be seen or even heard of in the game. Considering he made it out alive, one would think he would've at least tried to make contact with some of the folks who *did* get out, like Cor. *Comrades* reveals he's been working with Cor behind the scenes and serves as a party member during the tutorial.
[Alliterative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlliterativeName): **L**uche **L**azarus.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): Subverted during the recovery of Lunafreya, who had been kidnapped by Glauca; he arrives on board of a hijacked Niflheim gunship, ready to extract Nyx and Luna. Instead, he gets pushed off by one of Ultros's tentacles, leaving the pair to commandeer the ship themselves.
[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): His likeness is based on actor Greg Blackford, though different voice actors play him.

[Les Collaborateurs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LesCollaborateurs): He and a good portion of the Kingsglaive accept a deal with Niflheim to betray King Regis, in exchange for being able to return to their hometowns.

[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath): He is [burnt alive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOnFire) when he is rejected by the Ring of the Lucii, and ultimately falls off the building he and Luna are on.
[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): His treacherous and power-hungry ambitions leads to his death.

[Man on Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOnFire): He gets tricked into wearing the Ring of the Lucii by Luna, and is predictably rejected like Ravus before him, only this time his entire body is set aflame.

[Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl): He oversees the opening battle against Niflheim by relaying orders to the Kingsglaive, and directly reports to Drautos once the commander steps on the field.

[Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead): Last seen by Nyx and Luna being pushed off a ship by Ultros, Luche reappears much later alive and well. Except he shows his true colours by shooting Nyx and attempting to take the Ring.

[Schmuck Bait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait): Luna all but taunts him with the fact that he isn't powerful enough to wear the ring, with [the desired effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOnFire).
[Turncoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Turncoat): He is the leader of the rebel glaives who defect to Niflheim.

[Villain Ball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainBall): [He has Nyx at gunpoint and all he has to do is pull the trigger and recover the Ring from Luna.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDontYouJustShootHim) Instead, he decides *not* to kill Nyx and actually [opts to put on the Ring, even after Luna tells him that it's too powerful for him to wield.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive)

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Much of his characterization and importance to the plot comes after he's revealed to be among the Glaives who betray Regis, the moment the latter agrees to the peace treaty.

tropeName: Would You Like to Hear How They Died?
tropeNotes: [Would You Like to Hear How They Died?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldYouLikeToHearHowTheyDied): He gleefully describes Crowe's murder to Nyx, telling how one hollow bullet was all it took to make her die painfully while Nyx took two and still has the strength to move.

[Beauty Is Never Tarnished](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyIsNeverTarnished): [Averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope); she's already started to slightly decompose by the time her body is returned to Insomnia.
[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): Her appearance is based on actress Andrea Tivadar, though Crow herself is voiced by different actresses.
[Dies Wide Open](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiesWideOpen): When Libertus and Nyx hurry to the morgue to see her recovered corpse, her eyes are still open.
[Flies Equals Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FliesEqualsEvil): Her body is completely covered in a swarm of flies when discovered, which scatter when the unfortunate passersby who found her approach.
[Guys Smash, Girls Shoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuysSmashGirlsShoot): The mages among the Kingsglaive are all women, Crowe being the most prominent one.
[Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffscreen): In one scene, she is waiting for Luna to arrive. In the next scene, she is discovered dead.

[Like Brother and Sister](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeBrotherAndSister): With Libertus. Crowe is tired of hearing that she is like a little sister to him, but after the opening battle, she is right next to him as he is carried away on a stretcher, clearly worried about him.
[Military Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryMage): She stays back and provides support with the other mages.
[Nothing Is Scarier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NothingIsScarier): Her murder is not shown, though according to Lazarus she was shot to death and died screaming.

[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb): Just in case you didn't realize [what kind of film this is](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnyoneCanDie), she's the first named character to die, with her death causing the fracture between the Kingsglaive.
[The Squadette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSquadette): Crowe is the only prominent female Kingsglaive and indeed the only one voiced, save for another who groans after collapsing.
[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): Crowe is the sole prominent female Kingsglaive seen in the film.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): She is killed off early in *Kingsglaive* without being given much characterization.
[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): His likeness is based on actor Tausif Patel, though different voice actors play his role.

[I Owe You My Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOweYouMyLife): A good of part of his characterization lies on the fact that he feels heavily indebted to Nyx for saving his ass multiple times, and really wouldn't want the latter to go on dying without Pelna repaying his debt. For this, he is one of Nyx's most reliable allies within the Kingsglaive.

[Killed Mid-Sentence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledMidSentence): He reports to Nyx that he secured Luna, but at the same time ignores the former's warnings of an imminent trap. An Ultros immediately kills him for his trouble.
QUOTE "One Tenebrae princess, safe and soun—"
[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): One of the few Glaives who doesn't betray Lucis during the peace treaty, though he dies shortly before the rest turn *en masse*.
[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): His likeness is based on actor Mehran Armando, who doesn't voice the character.
[Fiery Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FieryRedhead): He has red hair and a hot-tempered personality.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): He openly discredits Lucis's decision to make a peace treaty with Niflheim, claiming that the ruling body doesn't really care for the lands beyond Insomnia and only handpicks the Kingsglaive for their affinity with Regis's magic. Then he moves on to belittle Nyx for his continued support towards the king, prompting the usually calm Nyx to get at his throat.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Unfortunately for Lucis, his grand speech is a sentiment held deeply by the majority of the Glaives, which is hinted at when Petra makes snide remarks at Nyx for being an immigrant.
[Killed Offscreen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffscreen): Libertus comes across his and his teammates' bodies when trying to regroup with the other civilian resistance members.
[Turncoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Turncoat): He is among the glaives who betray Regis.

tropeName: Ascended to a Higher Plane of Existence
tropeNotes: [Ascended to a Higher Plane of Existence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedToAHigherPlaneOfExistence): All of them are ancient Lucian kings who are long dead by present day, but their souls are contained within the Ring of the Lucii, the artifact that still links them to the mortal realm.
[Automatic Crossbows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AutomaticCrossbows): The Bow of the Clever is a crossbow that allows Noctis to fire several shots in a row without the need to reload.

[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): The Blade of the Mystic and the Sword of the Tall both qualify, as they're larger than Noctis when he wields them. And that's not getting started with the statues of the Old Wall, which all wield appropriately sized weapons.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy):  (SPOILER) In the [Updated Re Release](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedReRelease), Ardyn infects the Fierce, the Rogue and the Mystic with the Starscourge to force them to fight Noctis and his team while they're ascending the Citadel. Once defeated, their spirits are released, and they encourage the party to move forward.

[Bystander Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BystanderSyndrome): Though able to watch over the present and lend their power to the chosen few, they couldn't care less if Insomnia was razed, stating that mankind is foolish to dwell on the past.  (SPOILER) [Nyx calls them out on it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu), and convinces them to help stall Niflheim until Luna escapes the city with the Ring, albeit at the cost of Nyx's life.
[Chainsaw Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainsawGood): The Sword of the Tall is more chainsaw than sword. It even has the sound to match.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): The lore and the presentation of kings don't always match. The Shield of the Just was supposedly wielded by a Queen, but is used by an [extremely masculine-looking](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/finalfantasy/images/3/3a/The_Just_Artwork.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20180401164642) spirit. Likewise, the Bow of the Clever is used by a feminine figure, despite the [Flavor Text](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlavorText) describing it as being wielded by a King.
[Good Wings, Evil Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodWingsEvilWings): The Wise has angelic wings.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): They condemn humanity for their foolishness and ignoring the sacrifices they've made for them in *Kingsglaive* as they safeguard the future  (SPOILER) conveniently leaving out that the future they speak of protecting will kill most of humanity in the Starscourge and condemn them to a nightmarish fate until Noctis ends the plague.
[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): The Katana of the Warrior. Not always better against Daemons, or at least those who have Dark elemental attacks...

[Living Statue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingStatue): Several skyscraper-sized statues built in their image are strewn across the venues of Insomnia, and make up the legendary defense mechanic known as [the Old Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonIndicativeName). Should the bearer of the Ring of the Lucii wish so, the statues will awaken and relentlessly repel invaders.  (SPOILER) It turns out that these statues are imbued with the kings' souls. Smaller, but still imposing statues exist, being twice as tall as normal human. Ardyn infects the smaller statues of the Mystic, the Rogue and the Fierce with the Starscourge, and sics them on Noctis's party when they ascend the Citadel.

tropeName: Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me
tropeNotes: [Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe): The Shield of the Just, which is about as big as the Mystic and the Tall's weapons.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): The Wanderer has four arms.

[Mythical Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythicalMotifs): True to their covenant with Bahamut, the kings' armor designs borrow heavily from the Astral, who presents himself in dark armor with draconic designs. The Mystic's helmet is decorated by two wings on its top, and the back of his armor suit has something akin to a bony tail; the Rogue's headwear resembles a dragon with horns, she is known as the "Crouching Dragon King" in the Japanese version, and the French localization dubs her as "The Dragon".

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): They're the Knights of the Round summon from the previous *Final Fantasy* entries in all but name, as there are thirteen of them (eventually), they each carry an unique weapon, and they fight together by successively rushing a target.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Every king/queen is also known by an epithet, i.e., "the Tall", "the Wanderer", etc.

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice): Fond of doling these out to non-royal mortals in return for their aid. In Nyx's case it cost him his life, in Ignis' case it costs him his eyes.
[She Is the King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheIsTheKing): While they are collectively known as "Kings", several of them—namely the Rogue and the Just—were Queens.
[Shoulders of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShouldersOfDoom): The Just, the Fierce and the Tall have *massive* shoulder armor.

[Weaponized Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponizedTeleportation): The statues of the Old Wall display the terrifying capabilities of the Warp Strike placed on stories-tall warriors, as they make short work of Niflheim's fleet of warships and Diamond Weapons by moving at an incredibly fast pace.

[Ambition Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbitionIsEvil): He was always very ambitious, but as he grew older it turned into *hostile* ambition.  (SPOILER)  During the ascension ceremony, Somnus immediately interrupted it and claimed *he* was the king and Ardyn was a "traitor" he lured. After Somnus killed Aera, Ardyn became overcome with grief and succumbed to the Starscourge, ironically only then becoming the monster Somnus claimed he was.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero):  (SPOILER) While any interaction with him is colored by either Ardyn's (and by extension, the player's) antagonistic perception or the lack of information from his own point of view, it cannot be denied that by the time he was an adult, Somnus [Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass). [He took the extreme measure of killing and burning people with even the slightest sign of the Starscourge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) [to make up for the fact that having only ''one healer'' to help hundreds or thousands of infected would not do anything to slow it down and that to pretend otherwise would not be fair to anyone.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint) This came at the cost of [the people's favor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWithBadPublicity), worsening Somnus' [jealousy of Ardyn's glowing reputation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster).

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): With *Episode Ardyn Prologue* taken into account, and in the novelization in general, he's the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of *Episode Ardyn*, being ultimately responsible for Ardyn's [Protagonist Journey to Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProtagonistJourneyToVillain) aside from Bahamut's machinations.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): (SPOILER) While he spends the first half of the boss fight against Ardyn trying to justify his decisions, eventually he admits that he was jealous of not being 'special' or loved like Ardyn was. And at his defeat, he admits that he has no right to ask Ardyn's forgiveness for everything he did to him. QUOTE (SPOILER) **Somnus:** [I dare not ask for your forgiveness,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone) but I do ask [your understanding.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo) **Ardyn:** [What!?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigWhat) [You took everything from me--EVERYTHING--and you ask my understanding!?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero) **Somnus:** I pray your soul finds repose, Brother.
    - In *Dawn of the Future*, (SPOILER) he vouches for Ardyn when Noctis requests to grant him the power of the Ring of the Lucii, claiming it to be the first of many apologies.
[Bash Brothers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BashBrothers): With Gilgamesh,  (SPOILER) particularly in *Episode Ardyn Prologue,* where they murder Ardyn in tandem after he succumbs to the Starscourge.

[Big Brother Worship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherWorship): As stated by [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), Somnus never hated Ardyn (SPOILER) , even if he killed him for the throne, and looked up to him ever since he was a child. QUOTE **[Toru Osanai](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OaApHnC8gOU):** As for the brothers, Somnus and (SPOILER) Ardyn , it wasn't bad at all in their childhood. As mentioned before, they would play chess together when they were young and Somnus actually looked up to (SPOILER) Ardyn . (SPOILER) [Ardyn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct) [also took great care of his competitive little brother Somnus.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct) So they got along really well when they were young.

[Black-and-White Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndWhiteInsanity): Whereas his brother traveled the country curing people of the Starscourge, Somnus merely rounded up the infected and set them on fire. If the townsfolk are to be believed, *many weren't even infected.* He simply had to suspect it for many innocents to be condemned to a horrible and gruesome death. <sup>note </sup>  This may have been a result of comparing his methods to  (SPOILER) Ardyn's . According to *The Dawn of the Future,*  (SPOILER) Ardyn  believed in saving every single infected with his powers alone whereas Somnus believed doing so was impossible and also unfair to the people. Of course, the people favored  (SPOILER) Ardyn's  gentler method, leading to Somnus gaining a [reputation for ruthlessness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWithBadPublicity).  In the end this didn't even stop the Starscourge despite the brutality, it merely went dormant for a time before returning.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): He can create a cyclone with his sword that deals high damage.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The relationship between Somnus and Ardyn is played with a lot in this regard.  (SPOILER)  Somnus was always jealous of the popular and pious Ardyn who was favored by the Gods with healing abilities and favored as the one who would become the King. However, it is revealed Somnus was the one the Gods had chosen to be the King all along and was given the duty of imprisoning his brother so that he may be destroyed by his descendant the True King. To this end, Somnus tries to make excuses for himself to justify what he feels is his duty to his people over his brother.

[Combat Pragmatist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist):  (SPOILER)  During his duel with his brother, he used trickery and underhand tactics to gain the upper hand, such as utilizing the family's [Weaponized Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponizedTeleportation) to get past Ardyn's guard.

[Create Your Own Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreateYourOwnVillain):  (SPOILER) His betrayal of Ardyn was a major reason as to why Ardyn desires the death of the Lucis royal line (and, until then, a major reason for Noct and friends' suffering until then) .

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil)/[Dark Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil): The reason why black is the color of the royal family and all related to it, is because it's what Somnus wore and as ruthless as he was, [he had reasons to be so](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist).  (SPOILER) Ardyn would argue for him being the cause of his misery, though, and since he's playable along with Noctis, both tropes would be correct.  As the Mystic, he's more [Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood)/[Light Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsGood) instead.

[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Of *Episode Ardyn*, and from a meta perspective, due to the cancellation of Episodes Aranea, Lunafreya and Noctis; *[Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXV)* as a whole.
[Founder of the Kingdom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FounderOfTheKingdom): As the Founder King, he's Lucis's first ruler and the one who founded the kingdom 2000 years ago.
[Good Is Not Nice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotNice): As seen with his methods of dealing with the Starscourge.

[Good Old Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs): The statue of the Mystic breaks its sword against a Diamond Weapon during *Kingsglaive*'s climax, but then proceeds to engage in a fistfight with the kaiju-sized Daemon. The statue wins by punching through the monster's core. Against Ardyn in Episode Ardyn, he will also pound on him with his giant sized fists for a fair portion of the fight as well.

[Green-Eyed Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster):  (SPOILER)  He admits near the end of *Episode Ardyn* that he was jealous of his brother's healing gifts and popularity among the people and it was helped motivate him into obeying the Gods and betraying and imprisoning him. 
QUOTE   (SPOILER) **Somnus:** The gods blessed you as their chosen. The people adored you as their savior. I was never powerful nor popular...just envious, perhaps. I yearned desperately to be special, yet I had nothing to set me apart. Nothing at all.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn):  (SPOILER)  In *Dawn of the Future*, where he finally makes peace with Ardyn as both of them team up to defeat Bahamut once and for all .

[Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist): Of *Episode Ardyn*, the DLC being told from [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) Ardyn's perspective. That being said, it's only by virtue of his goal to end the Starscourge, as well as being the ancestor of *XV*'s hero Noctis, that Somnus is counted among the good guys. In fact, he's actually responsible for turning Ardyn into the man he is today.

[Historical Hero Upgrade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HistoricalHeroUpgrade): In the present he's remembered as the Founder King, who established the Caelum line after the Gods chose him to be a savior, and he traveled the world with the Oracle saving people from the Starscourge.  (SPOILER) In reality, he was a pawn of the Astrals meant to become the progenitor of the dynasty that would produce Noctis and was to imprison his brother in Angelgard by the will of the capricious gods.

[Identical Grandson](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalGrandson): As a human, he has the same dark hair and facial features as his descendant Noctis, though his personality and actions are the exact opposite. This is Discussed in *The Dawn of the Future*, where  (SPOILER) Noctis wonders if this is the reason Ardyn hates him so much.  This is taken even further when it is revealed that  (SPOILER) the both of them look just like *Bahamut*, and he wonders if the god always intended to put his own face on the throne .

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes:
[I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): A major part of his characterization and forms part of the reason why he  (SPOILER)  betrayed his brother. 
QUOTE   (SPOILER) **Somnus:** What I did to you was unforgivable, but I did it for the future of our kingdom—of our people. 
**Ardyn:** A small sacrifice for the good of society. How noble! 
**Somnus:** Our line has done everything in our power to protect our people, just as the gods bade. I was merely fulfilling my calling.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass):  (SPOILER) Taunting your brother after killing his fiancée? Dick move, Somnus, though again, it may be because *Prologue* takes Ardyn's point of view.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint):
    - Zigzagged. His method of burning the victims and innocents blamed for the illness was horrifying, to be sure, but managed to eventually curb it over time. Yet for all the death he caused, he was not thorough enough and the Starscourge returned several generations later naturally (SPOILER) and as Bahamut reveals, his brutal methods were always meant to be meaningless, as the plan was to have Ardyn spread the Starscourge on a scale that made Somnus's attempts to fight it utterly pointless with the number of lives consumed by it. - The novel clarifies and showcases this further (SPOILER) where he makes points about how his brother lets his chosen nature blind him to how he's not able to save everyone, and that his compassion and idealism were becoming a danger in themselves as it ended up vilifying his own actions. While its made clear he was in part motivated by jealousy with these opinions, even Ardyn came to the same realization after being imprisoned. As with the above, however, his solution to the problem is itself temporary, showing how neither solution could have lasted.
[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar):  (SPOILER) He burns people with even the slightest sign of the Starscourge in *Episode Ardyn Prologue.*

[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): As the kingdom's founder, the Mystic is ostensibly the leading figure among the twelve kings, as he takes the center figure in all of their appearances, and is  (SPOILER) the last of the twelve to oversee Noctis's ascension, shortly before Regis becomes the thirteenth spirit with the Sword of the Father and deals the final blow to Noctis .

[Ludicrous Mêlée Accuracy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LudicrousMeleeAccuracy): His statue accomplishes a very ridiculous feat in *Kingsglaive* by slashing Glauca, who's much, much smaller than the statue's [BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS), off the road without nailing Libertus and Luna's Audi, *while they and Glauca are moving at full speed on a highway*.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - *Somnus* is Latin for "sleep". In [Classical Mythology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Myth/ClassicalMythology), Somnus was the Roman god of sleep, and the brother of Mors, the personification of death, just as Somnus here is the brother of (SPOILER) Ardyn. - In the Japanese version, he is known as the "Yaksha King". In Hindu and Buddhist mythology, yaksha were benevolent — sometimes capricious — guardian spirits of nature, who were brethren to the demonic rakshasa. According to some legends, the yaksha also had a darker side akin to their brother-race. (SPOILER) His brother Ardyn's signature sword is known as the "Rakshasa Blade"; Somnus's own sword may well have simply been the "Yaksha Blade" before he became the Mystic.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes:
[My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): Implied in the [Royal Edition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedReRelease) when he speaks to Noctis (SPOILER) after being defeated as well as (SPOILER) [after killing his brother 2000 years before.](https://66.media.tumblr.com/34532de2a4adc9fbb837c2ef6b7232a9/tumblr_pn1ku4MwZR1szaani_400.png)◊ QUOTE **Somnus:** He's become the monster I made him out to be.
    - Confirmed by *Episode Ardyn,* *Dawn of the Future,* and a [developer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) [interview](https://fusetter.com/tw/kHNU0) that he feels this for (SPOILER) having to kill Ardyn for the throne.
QUOTE **Toru Osanai:** (SPOILER) Ardyn's and Somnus' passages through time are completely different. After (SPOILER) Ardyn was gone, Somnus established a nation and spent a long time protecting his people, all while carrying feelings of guilt at having done (SPOILER) his brother wrong. On the other hand, (SPOILER) Ardyn was imprisoned for about 2000 years without any knowledge of this, bringing about his "what makes you think you can apologize?!" sort of reaction. [His lines were intended to make the player feel the same emotions as him.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntendedAudienceReaction)

[Our Founder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurFounder): While Somnus is not the only king to have a statue built in his honor, as there are several more that make up the Old Wall around Insomnia's venues, the Mystic's statue has the honor of surviving the invasion of Insomnia *and* felling at least two Diamond Weapons, fighting alongside Nyx until the very end.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): The oldest of the kings is also most likely the strongest of them all, as shown in his duels with the Diamond Weapons, and  (SPOILER)  his own brother.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss):  (SPOILER) The Mystic's boss fight has two phases; one where Ignis deals the finishing blow, and a second where he changes the setting, adds warp strikes to his moves, and ends up defeated by a combination attack from Noctis and co.

[Sibling Yin-Yang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingYinYang): With his older brother  (SPOILER) [Ardyn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel), pre-betrayal. Ardyn was an idealist who sought to heal all infected with the Starscourge whereas Somnus was a realist [who gathered anyone with even the slightest sign of infection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) and [burned them all](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire) . Even so, they got along well until  (SPOILER) Somnus killed him for the throne .
[Sleepy Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SleepyHead): Evidently runs in House Caelum, as one of his hobbies is napping, according to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod).

[Tragic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicHero):  (SPOILER) With elements of [Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain). Yes, he *was* responsible for Ardyn becoming the cynical, ruthless, bitter monster that he is in the present, and he did do that partially out of jealousy, but as *Episode Ardyn* and *Dawn of the Future* reveals, the main reason why he condemned Ardyn was because it was truly what the Gods had done and he simply followed through what his family has always done: Protect the people at all cost and fulfill the wishes of the Gods. He truly did not feel happy over what he had done, and as he continued to rule, he came to genuinely regret what he had done. His last words to Ardyn before he fades away upon being defeated is genuinely solemn and pitiable, showing that rather than the power-hungry and remorseless sociopath willing to betray his own brother without remorse, he is more of a man who did what he believed he had no choice but to do and came to regret it as it didn't solve any of the problems he intended to solve. Even *Ardyn* himself in *Dawn of the Future* comes to this conclusion after meeting Bahamut and realizing how the War God truly was the one responsible for his suffering, seeing Somnus as ultimately nothing more but a pitiable pawn of Bahamut.
[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath):  (SPOILER) In the film, when Aera gets cut down, all he says is "foolish woman", though this does clash with his overall depiction somewhat.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn):  (SPOILER)  As awful as he is, it turns out he *and* Ardyn are both just pawns in the schemes of Bahamut, who is a million times worse than either of them .

tropeName: Used to Be a Sweet Kid
tropeNotes: [Used to Be a Sweet Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UsedToBeASweetKid): He was said to be a kind-hearted and energetic young boy in his youth - if a little over-competitive - and greatly looked up to his brother. Over the years, Somnus grew envious of his brother's gifts and popularity with the people. This eventually became part of his reason for  (SPOILER)  stealing the throne.  Meanwhile, his brother didn't care for it at all — he simply wanted to cure the Starscourge.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): See how much of his tropes are covered up? Not bad for someone who originally appeared as the main spokesperson of the Lucii in *[Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/KingsglaiveFinalFantasyXV)* and briefly in the base game as part of background lore before [The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal) and updates expanded on his role.

tropeName: What Is One Man's Life In Comparison?
tropeNotes: [What Is One Man's Life In Comparison?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatIsOneMansLifeInComparison): He was compelled when  (SPOILER) the Astrals made him King to imprison his brother and demonize him so that he would become [keystone of the starscourge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KeystoneArmy) even when jealous of his elder brother, Somnus' dialogue implies it broke his heart to do what he did to Ardyn but had to for the sake of the world .

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): (SPOILER) According to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), his desire for the throne was rooted in a completely genuine desire to protect the world, and everything he did in his eyes was for the greater good. He also took no pleasure in his coup. This heavily clashes with his downright glee at betraying Ardyn in the film, though that may be because it's from Ardyn's perspective or simply because he was acting. *Episode Ardyn* confirms that he ultimately was in fact aware of Ardyn being corrupted by the Starscourge and he did what he did because the Gods told him to.

[Written by the Winners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrittenByTheWinners):  (SPOILER) Even before ascending to the throne, Somnus starts his smear campaign against his brother, trying to convince his people that Ardyn is a traitor and a monster. After Ardyn succumbs to the Starscourge, the younger brother completely vilifies him to the point of [Un-Personning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnPerson) him and absolves himself of any guilt.
[Fuuma Shuriken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FuumaShuriken): The Star of the Rogue. It's not human-sized, but still pretty damn big.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She's a high-heeled, graceful, ninja, warrior-queen.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Crepera is derived from the Latin word *creper* ("dark"), and she's a reclusive ruler whose fighting style is optimal for dimly lit arenas.
[Ninja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ninja): The Rogue fights like a ninja in heels, using hit and run tactics and a dark arena to stay hidden.

[Shadow Dictator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowDictator): A benevolent example; the secretive Crepera didn't like appearing publicly, so she took to the shadows to enact her rule. Only after her passing did her heroic deeds become known.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow): She inherited the throne when her father and brother died during a Daemon crisis, leaving her to lead the kingdom even though she wasn't prepared for it.

[Beehive Barrier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeehiveBarrier):  (SPOILER) Upon being downed to critical health, the Fierce will deploy a spherical barrier that temporarily renders him invulnerable, though Gladiolus is able to break it open after parrying the Fierce's attack.

[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): His statue in *Kingsglaive* is hardly impressed by a Niflheim warship firing its main cannon through the statue's shoulder; this makes the statue turn its attention to the ship and wreck it with its remaining arm, before continuing the airborne rampage until it falls to the ground along with a Diamond Weapon (but not before punching the latter in the face).
[Beware the Nice Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheNiceOnes): He was a kind, just and loving king to his people. To his enemies, not so much.

[Carry a Big Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarryABigStick): The Mace of the Fierce is larger than its user, and predictably dishes out large amounts of pain. Just ask the poor Diamond Weapons and Niflheim warships that got smashed to oblivion by it.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): Employs gravity-based attacks.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): *Tonitrus* is Latin for "thunder", befitting his tempestuous nature.

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): Given his hulking size and the mace he carries, he strikes slowly, but if he so much as lands his hits even once, whoever's on the receiving end is in for a lot of pain.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): His armor's design has a lot in common with *[Final Fantasy X](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX)*'s Yojimbo.
[Samurai](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Samurai): He carries a giant mace, rather than a spear or sword, but otherwise his design looks like a cross between an ogre and a samurai.
[Cheerful Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CheerfulChild): Even in the wake of his grandfather's death he still finds a way to smile before long.

[Collection Sidequest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CollectionSidequest): Talcott collects cactaur figurines which you can help him find as a sidequest.  (SPOILER)  In the world of ruin he has the figures on the dashboard of his truck.

[Future Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FutureBadass): As an adult in the World of Ruin he is a hunter and [Adventure Archaeologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdventureArchaeologist) who aids Ignis in his research and saves people from Daemons.

[Geek](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Geek): He's an avid collector of Cactuar figurines, which Gladio describes as a "pretty grown up hobby", though it doesn't remotely diminish his enthusiasm for collecting the things. To say nothing of when he utterly flips his gourd when Noctis brings him a fancy and expensive Cactuar sculpture.
[He's All Grown Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HesAllGrownUp):  (SPOILER) Grows to a young adult during the World of Ruin, Noctis couldn't even recognize him at first.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): When in the  (SPOILER) World of Ruin, he is the one Noctis talks to for information about the state of the world and the rest of the extended cast .

[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure): Giving away the Crownsguard to  (SPOILER)  the Empire, leading to the death of Jared is his and haunts him a decade later in the World of Ruin .
[Survivor's Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorsGuilt): Blames himself for  (SPOILER) his grandfather's death.
[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): He is the youngest of all of Noctis's allies.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): When the Imperials come to Lestallum looking for Noctis,  (SPOILER) he unwittingly gives away that they are members of the Crownsguard, which leads to his grandfather's death.

[Wise Beyond His Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondHisYears): He is quite the scholar for his age, and even leads Noctis and his friends to a Royal Tomb from information he digs up in old journals.
[The Bartender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBartender): He owns a bar in Altissia.
[Bash Brothers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BashBrothers): He was this in the olden days, alongside Cid, Clarus and Regis.

[Casting Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingGag): His voice actor, Dave Fennoy, was one of the hosts during the Uncovered event. He was so ridiculously well-received (and liked by Tabata) that they made a character exclusively for him to voice.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): In addition to being a [Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass), he's just a very kind man in general helping Noct settle down in Altissia.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): His weapons of choice, though he also sometimes used a rapier.
[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): His combat style in *[A King's Tale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/AKingsTaleFinalFantasyXV).*
[High-Class Glass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassGlass): Wears a stylish monocle.
[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): He's modeled after his English voice actor, Dave Fennoy.
[Support Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportPartyMember): He is a party member in *[A King's Tale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/AKingsTaleFinalFantasyXV).*
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Used to be in the Crownsguard, but now lives a life of leisure as a bartender in Altissia.
[Royal Rapier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalRapier): He was mostly [The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger), but he did wield a slender rapier as well.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): Uses the word "lad" (and "lads") quite often.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): Doesn't have any of the Kingsglaive's magical powers, yet he manages to hold off a Niflheim gunship armed with just an armored truck and a machine gun.
[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): The likeness of actor Ryan Oliva is used for Petra's 3D model, while different voice actors play him.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Is openly racist towards Galahdians, and other "immigrants." Doesn't stop him from doing the right thing when it counts though, as detailed below.

[I Got You Covered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGotYouCovered): Arrives just in time to provide cover fire to Nyx and Luna against a Niflheim gunship, giving the two some respite. It's implied he dies holding off Tredd's group, as Libertus happens upon the wreckage of his truck.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Belittles Nyx for being an immigrant and questions the Kingsglaive's purpose in Lucis (given Insomnia already has the Crystal's impenetrable protection), but he's very keen on safekeeping the peace the city has enjoyed for over a hundred years.

[Offscreen Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffscreenMomentOfAwesome): Judging by Tredd's corpse and the surrounding wreckage, it's implied he somehow managed to shoot down a gunship with just a machine gun.

[Darker and Edgier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkerAndEdgier): Unlike the series' previous depictions of Gilgamesh, which have always been comedic in spite of also being a sufficient challenge, there's no joking around with this guy. Many expeditions by Lucis have always resulted in no discoveries... or survivors. Except Cor. You can see previous challengers lying dead around the caves, some of whom are [impaled to the cave's walls](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice).

[Flash Step](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashStep): Surprisingly, he is capable of phasing throughout his fight.  (SPOILER)  His aura is the same color as Ardyn's. The reason for this is because the Founder King, to whom Gilgamesh was the Shield, was Ardyn's *brother*.

[Good Is Not Nice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotNice): Gilgamesh is well-meaning in his trials meant to forge warriors worthy of the title of the King's Shield, but will not hesitate to outright slay those he considers unfit for the task.

[Handicapped Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandicappedBadass): In sharp contrast to how he's [usually presented in the series](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous), this version of Gilgamesh only has one arm ( (SPOILER) his left arm was sliced off by Cor when he took the trial ). It does very little to diminish his abilities, especially when he can create a spectral arm to replace the one he lost.

[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): During the first encounter with him Gladio cannot block his attacks and all of them will automatically break his guard. Combined with that, should you attack him you will deal pitiful damage, ineffective and only double digits.

[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): Gil's primary weapon is a large katana-type sword. The sword, known as the Genji Blade,  (SPOILER)  belonged to Cor in his youth, and was taken from him when he failed the Trials.  Upon his defeat, he gifts it to Gladio, who can use it both in the base game as well as an extension to his Maelstrom Glaive Art, Dual Master, where he summons it [to wield two greatswords at once](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding).

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): Similar to previous Gilgamesh iterations, this one's boss theme is a rendition of "Clash on the Big Bridge", only [this time](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DV8SJ57dgyU) it incorporates a bombastic orchestra *and* [Ominous Latin Chanting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousLatinChanting), making the song associated with a traditionally goofy character much more serious in nature.

[Master Swordsman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterSwordsman): Capable of completely overpowering Gladiolus even without an arm. After Gladio acquires the souls' blessings he can duel Gilgamesh on equal terms, which were required to [damage him at all](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerability). Even then he still manages to scar Gladio after he draws the Genji Blade.

[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): Fights skillfully with a [a plain broadsword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword), a [rapier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalRapier), a [greatsword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFreakingSword), and [a katana](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter), although the length is more similar to a nodachi befitting his size.

[My Master, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyMasterRightOrWrong): Whilst he himself is quite honorable,  (SPOILER)  him being complicit with all his liege lord's atrocities lands him squarely into this.
[Nigh-Invulnerability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerability): To even damage him you require a special aura around your weapon, one that disappears after he is defeated.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Gilgamesh has been around since the time of the Founder King, some 2,000 years prior to the events of the game, waiting for the arrival of a warrior worthy enough to serve as the True King's Shield. *How* he's managed this is never really addressed, though cut dialogue from *Episode Gladiolus* suggests he tied his soul to the Trial Grounds after Ardyn's first defeat to prepare future generations for the return of the Immortal Accursed. The fact he has [Glowing Eyes of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyesOfDoom) in the present day but not in the distant past does imply he's currently of a supernatural nature.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): The Blademaster.

[Secret Test of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretTestOfCharacter): Both he and the souls who bar the way to him spend the trial taunting Gladiolus that a Shield burdened by fear is unfit to serve, and as Gladio *is* afraid, he will fail the trials and die.  (SPOILER) After Gladio defeats Gilgamesh and admits he *is* afraid but is going to keep trying anyway, Gilgamesh reveals that is the true essence of a worthy Shield — not to have no fear, but to serve in their duties in spite of it.

[Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect): Holds his last challenger in deepest respect, who claimed his arm yet lost regardless. In honor of that, he kept his weapon which he uses in his second phase. His respect spread to his army, who look down on Gladiolus due to their belief he cannot match his predecessor.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Apart from *Episode Gladiolus* and *Episode Ardyn: Prologue*, Gilgamesh never makes any other appearances; whatever became of him after  (SPOILER) the fulfillment of the prophecy  is never brought up.

[You Don't Look Like You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouDontLookLikeYou): Unlike previous appearances, Gilgamesh drops [the other five arms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous) and aims to kill you [single-handedly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pun).
[Achilles' Heel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AchillesHeel): Without her trident, Luna is powerless and cannot use magic.
[Action Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionSurvivor): She survives the devastating attack on Insomnia and goes to seek out Noctis.

[Advertised Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdvertisedExtra): She's billed as the game's main heroine, and side materials such as *[Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/KingsglaiveFinalFantasyXV)* and the Brotherhood anime set her up to be a prominent figure, but she only appears for roughly half an hour of the 30+ hour game, and even then very little of it is spent interacting with the main heroes and/or  (SPOILER) alive . Especially egregious in the *Royal Edition*, where she appears on the cover of the game, but her added screentime amounts to a brief cutscene of  (SPOILER) her spirit appearing to provide a [Deus ex machina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeusExMachina) to help the heroes get past a magic barrier, with little in the way of new insight on the character .

[Ancestral Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncestralWeapon): The Trident of the Oracle is a very powerful [Ancient Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncientArtifact) passed down the Fleuret family from one Oracle to the next, in fact without their trident the Oracles are all but powerless. It is the only one of the Royal Arms that Noctis obtains not to belong to a Lucian King or Queen.

[Anime Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimeHair): A subversion. Her hairstyle is doable in real-life (it was actually designed by a professional hair stylist hired by Square), but is *extremely* intricate and complex. It's actually very similar to  (SPOILER) Shiva's , which implies that more likely than not Gentiana does her hair.

[Anti-Anti-Christ](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiAntichrist):  (SPOILER) In the *Dawn Of The Future* novel, she was resurrected by Bahamut in order to succeed Ardyn as being [The Antichrist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAntichrist) to oppose Noct's [Messianic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MessianicArchetype), and act as his [Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb) to destroy the Starscourge. She instead plots to exhaust his power to put him to sleep, but not before succumbing to the Starscourge after absorbing too much of it when freeing Ifrit .

[Arranged Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArrangedMarriage): As part of the peace treaty between Lucis and Niflheim, she is to marry Noct. But it turns out that it was a ruse by Niflheim to steal Lucis's [Power Crystal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCrystal).

tropeName: Ascend to a Higher Plane of Existence
tropeNotes: [Ascend to a Higher Plane of Existence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendToAHigherPlaneOfExistence): She  (SPOILER) becomes one with the spirit realm  after her death and is eventually joined by  (SPOILER) Noctis in the post-credits stinger .

[Back from the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackFromTheDead): She is  (SPOILER) resurrected by Bahamut in *Dawn of the Future*, after Ardyn throws a wrench into the Astral's plans by refusing to play along .

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast):
QUOTE *(To Leviathan)* "I vow—the King *will* prove himself worthy!" 
"This I solemnly vow, upon my honor as Oracle: I will not rest until the Darkness has been banished from our world, and the Light restored!"

[Barrier Maiden](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierMaiden): As an Oracle, her powers are the only thing preventing the world from being plunged into eternal darkness. Appropriately after she is  (SPOILER) killed by Ardyn, the world slowly descends into the [The Night That Never Ends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNightThatNeverEnds).

[Beneath the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeneathTheMask): For a single cutscene, Luna lets her composure slip to Ravus that she is terrified her failing health will soon render her unable to fulfill her duty and make her a burden.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes):  (SPOILER) In the *Royal Edition*, she appears in spirit form to call upon the Astrals to destroy a swarm of incoming demons and break down the wall blocking the group's path to Ardyn.

[Came Back Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameBackWrong): In the *Dawn of the Future* novel, Lunafreya is resurrected by Bahamut. Normally, this would be all well and good...except she's been given the same abilities as Ardyn.
[Cast from Lifespan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromLifespan): Forging a covenant with the Six is a debilitating process to the Oracle to the point of putting Luna on death's door.

[Childhood Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriends): Noctis once visited her homeland of Tenebrae when he was being treated for his injuries after being attacked by a Marilith, there she and Noctis grew close until the Empire's invasion separated them.
[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): To help contrast her [Color Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorMotif) from Noctis's, she is generally dressed in white.

[Comic-Book Fantasy Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicBookFantasyCasting): Her likeness in *[Kingsglaive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/KingsglaiveFinalFantasyXV)* is based on Russian model Sonya Maltceva, though different voice actresses play her.

[Cosmic Keystone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicKeystone): As the Oracle she is the only person capable of healing people of the Starscourge affliction.  (SPOILER) It's for this reason that Ardyn kills her, removing the only person capable of holding the Starscourge from blighting all of Eos and plunging the world into [The Night That Never Ends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNightThatNeverEnds).

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): She will see to it that Noctis ascends and receives the power that is rightfully his, and absolutely *nothing* will stop her. Not General Glauca, not a broken-down airship, not even *[Leviathan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassGod)*, and certainly not  (SPOILER) Ardyn gutting her .

[Deuteragonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Deuteragonist): Luna is the "keystone" that connects the entire *Final Fantasy XV* Universe; she is the only character that has a leading role in all installments. The main story depicts not only Noct's journey, but hers as well.
QUOTE *Fifteen years ago... Their journey began.*

[The Dog Bites Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDogBitesBack): After years of quietly accepting her fate as the Oracle, she ultimately  (SPOILER) rebels against her ordained duty once she learns that not only is her beloved Noctis supposed to die, too, but that Bahamut intends to destroy Eos entirely.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): She unwillingly becomes this to Noctis in *Dawn of the Future* courtesy of  (SPOILER) Bahamut, who has her absorb the Starscourge itself to fuel Tera Flare, thus turning her into the "Queen of Darkness", just as how Bahamut planned to have Noct absorb the Crystal's light to fuel Providence, making him the "King of Light".
[The Exile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExile): After the invasion of Insomnia, Luna went into self-imposed exile to hide from Niflheim.

[Fallen Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenPrincess): Her family was stripped of its title but she retains some authority within her country, not as its former princess, but as the [Oracle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighPriest).

[The Farmer and the Viper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFarmerAndTheViper): She tries to comfort Ardyn, apparently believing that he is not evil [of his own free will](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession). He backhands her in response.

[Fearless Fool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FearlessFool): She's a strong-willed person who, by her own words, does not fear death, though in *Kingsglaive* Nyx rolls his eyes at her no less than three times during the mission to retrieve her from a Niflheim warship, as he ends up having to prevent her from doing anything reckless.

[Forced to Watch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedToWatch): The death of Regis at Glauca's hands in *Kingsglaive*. All she can do is stare as the king of Lucis gets [Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice).
[Gaussian Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GaussianGirl): She's presented this way in the TGS 2014 trailer after the boys bring her up, complete with hazy motes of light around her.

[Gender-Restricted Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderRestrictedAbility): The position of Oracle is passed only down to the women of the Fleuret family, unlike the power of the Caelums, which has been passed down through Kings and Queens. That said, the males still apparently do receive bits and pieces of an Oracle's power, like Ravus's [Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength)—just not the entire package, like the healing or the ability to call upon and communicate with Astrals.

tropeName: Girly Girl with a Tomboy Streak
tropeNotes: [Girly Girl with a Tomboy Streak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlyGirlWithATomboyStreak): As shown by the *Dawn of the Future* novel, not only is she trained in Polearm combat, given proper instruction, she's surprisingly helpful in repairing a motorcycle.

[Gold and White Are Divine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldAndWhiteAreDivine): Her primary color scheme is white, [she’s fair skinned, blond haired and as benevolent as they get.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold) Radiates a heavenly gold aura when using her powers as an oracle, has a very divine appearance with angelic beauty and communes with the gods to help Noctis save the world even though using her powers is causing her body to fail.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): Luna has blonde hair and has an affable nature.
[Heroes Love Dogs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesLoveDogs): Luna has two dogs, the black furred Umbra and the white furred Pryna.
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): As Luna's body increasingly weakens, she  (SPOILER) briefly abandons her duty as Oracle and asks Ravus to take the Ring to Noctis in her place.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Luna uses the remaining power she has to  (SPOILER)  help Noctis fight Leviathan and heal him when she could have saved herself from the wound she received from being stabbed by Ardyn.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): She has a few interesting quirks that not many people, Noctis included, know about her. For starters, despite her non-action status, she is incredibly skilled in the use of polearms and staves, courtesy of her Oracle training. She's also a little bit of a gearhead, knowing well enough about motorcycles to help Sol repair and maintain her Regina — which effectively puts Noctis and the Chocobros to shame as they are *helpless* without Cindy working on the Regalia. Her sternness is also a bit of a mask — she confides in Gentiana that she is far more excited about her wedding to Noctis than she lets on, while alone with her brother, admits that her [Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel) are something of a facade she puts on for the sake of others', and that her destiny deeply saddens and terrifies her.

[High Priest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighPriest): Or "Priestess" in her case. The Oracle is a major religious authority and because of this, the Empire cannot fully assimilate Tenebrae without risking civil unrest from the rest of the world.
[I Choose to Stay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IChooseToStay): She had an opportunity to escape Tenebrae as it was being conquered, but ran back to be with her brother.
[Improvised Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprovisedWeapon): The staff she wields in the *Dawn of the Future* novel is little more than a strong tree branch, not that she didn't make it work.

[Insecure Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsecureLoveInterest): Luna fears that she "has nothing to offer" Noctis other than her role as Oracle. This is insecurity rather than reality — she has the compassion of a saint, a will of pure steel, and the courage to stand up to an enraged [Jerkass God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassGod) who tries to kill her and Noctis. She is also definitely in the running for most beautiful woman in all of Eos.

[In-Series Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InSeriesNickname): A lot of the people who know her personally, including Noct and his friends, call her "Luna" instead of her full name of Lunafreya. Meta-wise, she's also usually referred to as "Luna" by the development staff.
[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): She's the last of the Oracles.

[Light Feminine and Dark Feminine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightFeminineAndDarkFeminine): Downplayed. The light feminine to Gentiana's dark feminine. Luna is [an all loving heroine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLovingHeroine), wears white, is kind, has angelic beauty and glows with a heavenly aura. Gentiana wears dark colors, is mysterious and somewhat aloof, and her beauty looks like something you'd expect from a [Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic) to contrast with Luna's [White Magician Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMagicianGirl) look.
[Light Liege, Dark Defender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightLiegeDarkDefender): The light liege to Nyx Ulric's dark defender in Kingsglaive.

[Locked Out of the Loop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedOutOfTheLoop): *Dawn of the Future* reveals that Luna has *no* idea about what Noctis must ultimately do to banish the darkness fronm Eos.  (SPOILER) She does not take the news of his upcoming death well.
[Loved by All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovedByAll): A perk of being an Oracle is that nearly everyone loves her.

[Masculine Girl, Feminine Boy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasculineGirlFeminineBoy): Personality-wise Masculine Girl to Noctis’s Feminine Boy. [When comparing the personalities of Noctis and Lunafreya, Tabata referred to Noctis as the weaker of the two, with Luna being the stronger one.](http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2015/08/05/new-story-details-from-final-fantasy-xv-s-director.aspx) She is the alpha in their relationship since she's proactive, being more likely to create or control a situation by causing something to happen, is resolved to see her duties through no matter what, in spite of the numerous tragedies she has endured all from a young age, largely by herself and comes across as more fit and ready to lead a country in addition to being strong willed and independent. [In contrast Noctis is shy, indecisive in stressful situations, faint of heart with his duties, needs the support of others in order to cope with tragic events, needs to grow more before being ready to lead a nation, and responds to critical events rather than creating them.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil)
    - Justified since Luna had to [toughen up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass) after her parents are killed, Ravus joins the Empire and Tenebrae gets occupied. While Noctis lives a rather [sheltered and pampered life in Insomnia.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShelteredAristocrat)

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Lunafreya" is a [Portmanteau](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Portmanteau) of the Latin word for moon and the Norse goddess of the same name, "Nox" means night, while "[Fleuret](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalRapier)" refers to her *predecessor's* weapons.
    - In the Japanese version, *frena* is the plural of the Latin *frenum* ("bridle").

[The Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMentor): Being the older of the two, Luna was the one who told Noctis about their roles as [The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne)s. The "Omen" trailer intercuts dialogue of them reassuring each other with a scene of  (SPOILER) [a crazed older Noctis killing her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorOccupationalHazard). Though in the game, [it turns out that Ardyn is the one to kill her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverTrustATrailer).

[Mentor Occupational Hazard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorOccupationalHazard): Years after telling Noctis about their roles as [The Chosen Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne),  (SPOILER) she is tragically killed by Ardyn .

[Minored In Ass Kicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinoredInAssKicking): While Luna never displayed any physical capabilities aside from tanking Leviathan's attacks no worse for wear in the game proper, *Dawn of the Future* reveals that all Oracles receive combat training in spears and tridents as part of their grooming. While she did complete the training, she has admittedly put regular practice on the backburner due to focusing on her duties as a healer.  (SPOILER) After she is revived in the World of Ruin, she finds herself quickly needing to get back in the groove of it to fend off the daemons, though it's made somewhat easier now that she also sports Ardyn's powers in addition to her own.

[Minor Major Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinorMajorCharacter): While she plays an important role in the universe's lore and plot, her actual screentime clocks in at roughly half an hour of screentime and whatever relevance she has to the story is communicated almost entirely via exposition and third-hand accounts.
[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): Her mother, Queen Sylva, died during Niflheim's invasion of Tenebrae in *Kingsglaive*.
[Mystical Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWaif): Even as a child she spoke quite eloquently and seriously about the Oracle and King's duties.

[Naginatas Are Feminine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NaginatasAreFeminine): She's trained in Polearm combat, and, in the *Dawn of the Future* novel, Sol noted that she wields her staff with the finesse of a trailed warrior.

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): She is definitely not a woman easily shaken.
