[Locked Out of the Loop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedOutOfTheLoop):  (SPOILER) If the memories Ardyn receives from Ifrit after forging a Covenant and infecting him with the Starscourge are to be believed, Ifrit was not made aware that Ardyn was meant to spread the Starscourge, as the memories show Ardyn being absorbed into the Crystal and become the Founder King. As further evidence, he calls Ardyn "a man from House Caelum." Bahamut and Shiva, and presumably the other Astrals, know Ardyn is the Immortal Accursed and refer to him as such, but Ifrit does not recognize him.
[Loincloth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Loincloth): The only real clothing he's wearing.

[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice): Shiva's counterpart in this regard as well, he pretty much wears nothing save a loincloth and takes the appearance of a *very* handsome looking humanoid.

[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): He's of the fire element, being a retake of the recurring fire summon of the *[Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/FinalFantasy)* series.
[Red Baron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedBaron): Aside from the official moniker "Infernian", Ifrit is also sometimes known as the Betrayer or the Pyreburner.
[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge): His hatred for humanity is justified in his backstory,  (SPOILER) where humans started spurning his gifts .
[Satanic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatanicArchetype): Invoked by his role and devilish appearance.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): His extended backstory as detailed by  (SPOILER) Shiva  includes granting the gift of fire to humans after admiring their strength of will, similar to Prometheus from [Greek Mythology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Myth/ClassicalMythology). His demonic appearance and role as the enemy of humanity also set him up as a [Satanic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatanicArchetype), even implying him to be responsible for creating the Starscourge.  (SPOILER) *Episode Ardyn* reveals he was just a pawn, however, and was afflicted with the Starscourge by Ardyn himself mere decades ago. *Dawn of the Future* reveals the legend of the War of the Astrals is a lie, and Bahamut ultimately usurped him as the *true* enemy of humanity; arguably his rebellion against Bahamut *enforces* his role as Satan .
[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): In his first phase of battle, he shoots blasts of fire while slouched over.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): A series example. Commonly one of the earliest obtainable summons, Ifrit's usually quite weak... but in *XV*, he is anything but weak and has seriously stepped up his game. At the end of the main story,  (SPOILER) not only is he one of the last bosses, he completely parkours through Bahamut's *ultimate attack* and parries his main sword, *shrugs off* a direct hit **to the head** by a ten-years-older Crystal-empowered Noctis, then needed to be frozen solid by Shiva (who is an example of this trope as well). *Episode Ardyn* also shows that Bahamut's Ultima Sword is capable of defeating him in combat, giving more weight to his performance in the main game .

[Unusable Enemy Equipment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnusableEnemyEquipment): Ifrit is this. He is the only Astral Noctis cannot form a Covenant with  (SPOILER) because Ardyn already beat him to it and used the Starscourge to further reduce Ifrit into a mindless thrall.

[The Voiceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoiceless): Ironically, he's the only Astral besides Ramuh to never say a word on-screen, save for a few roars and growls during his boss fight, contrasting his extremely vicious nature.  (SPOILER) This is because the Ifrit Noctis and co. encounter has been reduced to a mindless beast, courtesy of Ardyn. [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subverted) in *Episode Ardyn*, where he does speak before his corruption, albeit in the Astral language .
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): Has no shirt at all.

[Always Chaotic Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysChaoticEvil): This is never outright stated but strongly implied. After all, the reason [The Night That Never Ends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNightThatNeverEnds) is such a terrifying apocalyptic scenario would be due to this trope; if they were just solitary animals that wanted to be left alone instead of ones that actively hunted humans for whatever reason they wouldn't be so highly feared.

[Demon of Human Origin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonOfHumanOrigin): Daemons are actually the result of other beings, such as humans or animals, being parasitized by [the Starscourge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalPlague).
[Evil Makes You Ugly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMakesYouUgly): Most daemons are twisted monsters with an otherwordly appearance, in contrast to the more realistic creatures found during daytime.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Several daemons are recurring enemies from previous *Final Fantasy* games.

[Nocturnal Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NocturnalMooks): They operate in the nighttime,  (SPOILER) or during [the Starscourge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNightThatNeverEnds) , due to being [Weakened by the Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakenedByTheLight).

[Our Demons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDemonsAreDifferent): They're examples of [Demon of Human Origin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonOfHumanOrigin), and they are [Weakened by the Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakenedByTheLight).

[Weakened by the Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakenedByTheLight): A common trait is that they are hurt by strong sources of light, which is why they are only encountered at night or in places like caves and avoid illuminated areas. That said, most of them are far stronger than the wildlife encountered during the day.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): All of her human limbs carry a sword, and is a fairly tough opponent for Noctis's party.
[Off with His Head!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffWithHisHead): After dismembering her, Noctis goes for the kill by beheading her.
[Reptiles Are Abhorrent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReptilesAreAbhorrent): Her lower body is that of a giant serpent, and she's quite vicious.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): The Marilith in *Brotherhood* is the creature that triggered Noctis's journey to Tenebrae, which in turn sparked Niflheim's invasion of the kingdom, leading straight to the events of *[Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/KingsglaiveFinalFantasyXV)* and *Brotherhood*.

[Attack Its Weak Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackItsWeakPoint): They have an obvious core glowing red on their chest, implying it's their weak point. The problem is, these monsters are skyscraper-sized, so there's next to nothing that can dent them. Fortunately, the statues of the Old Wall are equally gigantic and they manage to take down the creatures by the end of Insomnia's sacking.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): As noted by Verstael in *Episode Prompto*, full sublimation of the consciousness was impossible with the Diamond Weapons, resulting in ego death. As a result they're damn near impossible to control and immediately go into a destructive rampage when activated. In *Kingsglaive*, the Empire's strategy is basically "set them loose and *hope* they mostly focus on Lucian forces" - they hoist them to a battlefield with multiple airships, awaken them and let them run wild.

[Defeat Equals Explosion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatEqualsExplosion): One of these creatures violently bursts into an explosion that lights up the skies after being impaled through the core by the Mystic statue's sword during *Kingsglaive*'s climax.

[Kaiju](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kaiju): One of the largest monsters seen in *XV*'s universe, much emphasis is put on their size and overwhelming firepower during the movie, with scenes even depicting them as terrorizing the populace. That is, [until they end up facing the Old Wall's statues](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BehemothBattle).

[More Dakka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDakka): Their main method of attack is the massive barrage of projectiles fired from their shoulders. One volley is enough to destroy an entire city block. And Niflheim deploys many of them during Insomnia's sacking.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): They're practically a modernized render of *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)*'s own Diamond Weapon.

[Ominous Fog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousFog): In *Kingsglaive*'s opening battle, the Diamond Weapon's entire body is pouring out miasma: smoke that is released due to damage inflicted by sunlight, as the entire construct is made up out of in-numerable daemons inhabiting and powering the Magitek armor, making it hard to see anything but a towering cloud with red eyes that viciously dispels the firestorm conjured by Crowe's team. Other Diamond Weapons presented during the sacking of Insomnia do not exhibit this trait, as they are not taking damage from the sun.
[Red Eyes, Take Warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning): With red glowing eyes, core and shoulder appendages, these things are more of a weapon of mass destruction than actual creatures.

[Shoulders of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShouldersOfDoom): Concept art shows that their openable shoulders are inspired by a carnivore's jaw. They're large enough to house dozens of smaller Daemons and fire hundreds of explosive projectiles.

[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath): The Cerberus that appears in *Kingsglaive* dies falling into the chasm created by the Diamond Weapon's rampage. Distracted while pursuing Nyx and Libertus, the Cerberus simply couldn't get a hold of the crumbling ground.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): First appears in *Kingsglaive*, where one is fought and defeated by Nyx. A group of them surrounding Noctis are also glimpsed at in the "Omen" trailer. Both appearances are showcased long before its actual appearance in the [Royal Edition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease), where it serves as  (SPOILER) the Citadel's gate guardian and a boss right before Ifrit .
[Evil Is Burning Hot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsBurningHot): It's a fire-elemental Daemon.
[Fluffy the Terrible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FluffyTheTerrible): Ardyn refers to the Cerberus  (SPOILER) stationed before the Citadel's gates  as his "little pet". It's anything *but*.
[Hellhound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hellhound): It's a truck-sized, three-headed snarling hound that relentlessly attacks its prey.

[Last Breath Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastBreathBullet):  (SPOILER) If you've completed Cor's sidequest and brought him with you to Insomnia Ruins, an additional cutscene plays where the defeated Cerberus springs up one last time and launches a fireball at Noctis before keeling over for good. Cor shields Noctis from the attack, but is left incapacitated, explaining why the party enters the Citadel without him.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Its appearance is modeled after its *[Final Fantasy VIII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIII)* incarnation's.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Employs fire-based attacks.
[Throat Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThroatLight): Or rather throat *fire*, as these beasts' mouths are perpetually lashing out flames.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Its design has more in common with the Omega Weapon from *[Final Fantasy X](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX)*, down to the centaur-like lower body, segmented armor and large claws.

[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): One of the superbosses only accessible through a sidequest, Naglfar brings the pain to Noctis and co. with its absurd damage output and sizeable health pool.

[Damage-Sponge Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamageSpongeBoss): The greatest example within the game, as it takes a ridiculous amount of time to whittle down its health while the Adamantoise itself barely does more than moving around without even registering the party's presence (and even then, its size means you can take damage just from that). However, a later update allowed it to be easily given a one-hit kill by the Ring of the Lucii.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): The moment you take the hunting bounty for it, *everyone* in Lucis is gone, with a message saying they went into hiding once the Adamantoise got out of its shell. Noctis's party is [completely incredulous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveGotToBeKiddingMe) when he decides to fight the Adamantoise, as it's more of a mountain than a creature.
QUOTE **Prompto:** Dude, you can't be serious. [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap), you are! Noct! C'mon man, not cool!

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): *Very* subtly done. Prompto often asks Noctis to stop the Regalia so he can take pictures of beautiful or at least impressive landmarks. However, he also wants to shoot a fairly small and completely unremarkable mountain in the middle of nowhere that you might pass by very early in the game...

tropeName: He Was Right There All Along
tropeNotes: [He Was Right There All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWasRightThereAllAlong): The mountain that's actually its shell is less than a mile away from [Hammerhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstTown) and can be seen and visited at any time. You might've even posed for a picture in front of it at some point.

[Marathon Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MarathonBoss): Depleting its health takes around one whopping hour on average, and even the best combos can only do so much to reduce it to thirty minutes. It was, after all, designed to be a boss that needed about 72 in-game hours to take down.  (SPOILER)  With the Ring of the Lucii, a heavily magic-specced character, and a bit of luck with a max-level party, you can down the beast in under fifteen minutes, but it's still extremely challenging, and your reward [is just a trophy, an extremely valuable Adamantite item, and some cooking ingredients](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraggingRightsReward), although the latter also have some actual use for crafting [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) magic.

[Metal Slime](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetalSlime): Ever since the Adamantoise was made susceptible to the Ring of the Lucii's [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) spells, it has become one of the most popular farming targets for experience points (at least 50,000 per run) and Limit Break magic ingredients (up to 26 charges per run). Not really surprising, considering that one run takes a mere 10 minutes and is a completely safe endeavour (the Adamantoise can't hurt you if you stay at the edge of its aggro radius).

[Stationary Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StationaryBoss): The only superboss in the game that doesn't move an inch while you fight it, making it *the* prime target for the [Alterna spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill). That being said, the Adamantoise can deal incredible amounts of damage simply by scraping the ground with its flippers or moving its head around thanks to its mind-boggling size.
[That's No Moon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon): That mountain over there? It's not actually a mountain...

[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): Stated to be the oldest living creature known to man, said to be born at the dawn of time itself. And you probably killed it for shits and giggles. [You Bastard!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouBastard).

[Turtle Island](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurtleIsland): **The** biggest creature in the game. This thing is as large as a mountain, and indeed is [mistaken for a mountain called Longwythe Peak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon) for most of the game. In-game data puts the Adamantoise's size at 2,340 ft and its weight at 17,400,000 tons. Only the Astrals, the *literal gods of this setting*, can rival it in sheer size. Its idle movements alone trigger earthquakes and have absolutely everyone [bolt for cover](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere) the moment it reveals itself.
[Kraken and Leviathan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KrakenAndLeviathan): From the small glimpses you get to see from him while you're out on the ocean, he's several times your yacht's size.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): To the Esper from *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*, who took the form of a whale.
[Sadly Mythtaken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadlyMythtaken): The wire monument of "Leviathan" you find in Altissia's Listro Park is actually that of Bismarck.
[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Much like in previous installments, there's really no indication of Carbuncle's gender.
[Auto-Revive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AutoRevive): Summoning them brings the whole party back up to full health if Noctis's HP is brought down to zero.
[Dream Walker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DreamWalker): Heavily implied to be this.
[Fantastic Foxes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticFoxes): They look much more fox-like than in previous entries.

[Funny Background Event](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunnyBackgroundEvent): Like Gentiana, Carbuncle will also [occasionally](https://www.reddit.com/r/FinalFantasy/comments/5fqlys/ffxv_anyone_else_get_a_superfluous_carbuncle_in_a/) photobomb Prompto's pictures, though unlike with her, Carbuncle doesn't have a trophy for it, and is noticeably less common.
[Hello, [Insert Name Here]](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelloInsertNameHere): Can be named by the player at the end of the *Platinum Demo*.
[Mentor Mascot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorMascot): Along with Gladio, they serve as Noct's instructor in the game's tutorial.
[Our Angels Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurAngelsAreDifferent): They're one of the 24 Messengers of the Gods.
[Ridiculously Cute Critter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyCuteCritter): As per usual. Their vulpine appearance certainly helps.

[Spirit Advisor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiritAdvisor): Carbuncle is Noct's stalwart mental companion, accompanying him through the dreamscapes that comprise the *Platinum Demo*, the tutorial portion of *FFXV* proper and the Moogle Chocobo Festival DLC.

[Talking Animal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingAnimal): Communicates with Noctis via smartphone text messages, similar to [Celty Sturluson](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/Durarara). They even use emoji, sometimes. It's implied that they deliver these text messages telepathically, though the Moogle Chocobo Festival DLC shows Noctis referring to his phone while talking to them during the fireworks.
[Canine Companion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanineCompanion): To Luna and later, Noctis.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): A nonfighting variation for Umbra, who travels with Noct upon his reawakening in  (SPOILER) the World of Ruin and until the two are saved and delivered to Hammerhead by Talcott.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Pryna is derived from the Latin *pruina* ("rime/hoarfrost"), and is also a Welsh word meaning "purchase/redeem", while Umbra is Latin for "shadow".
[Our Angels Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurAngelsAreDifferent): Like Gentiana and Carbuncle, they're Messengers of the Gods.
[Pale Females, Dark Males](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaleFemalesDarkMales): Pryna (female) has white fur, while Umbra (male) has black fur.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): To [Geri and Freki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geri_and_Freki), [the wolves of Odin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Myth/NorseMythology).
[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Prompto taking in an injured Pryna after he found her near his house, led to Prompto becoming one of Noctis's closest comrades.
[Time Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeMaster): Umbra can transport Noctis back to Lucis (and later, Altissia) in the past.

[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): (SPOILER) After only appearing in Episode 2 and a couple of Ultimate Collector's Edition-exclusive scenes from *Brotherhood* and a few brief scenes in *XV*, Pryna dies offscreen during the events of Chapter 9. She does turn up later on to aid Prompto during the *Episode Prompto* DLC (which takes place alongside Noctis's trip on the train); however, given that it's during the scene where Prompto confronts his inner child, it's very likely that it's just all in Prompto's head.
    - (SPOILER) Her death is finally shown on-screen during *Episode Ignis*, where the last thing she does before expiring is to give Ignis a vision of the future of Noctis's sacrifice to defeat Ardyn.

[Contractual Boss Immunity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContractualBossImmunity): Unlike the Adamantoise, another superboss, it cannot be killed by the Death spell, so you'll really have to fight this boss fair and square, which is a daunting task in itself.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): In the words of Gentiana:
QUOTE "Its might knows no equal. The wise dare not cross its path, lest they meet their end."
[Energy Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyWeapon): In true Omega fashion, the angler-like appendage on its top fires a bright red laser beam when you're too close to it.
[Giant Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantMecha): Like its previous incarnations, it's a four-legged, tank-sized automaton designed to kill gods.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): It simply warps out of thin air once you reach a certain area in the final chapter, and even then, it's definitely not under Ardyn's command as it aimlessly roams the area.
QUOTE **Prompto:** What kind of interdimensional nonsense is this?

QUOTE **Gladio:** [Bad interdimensional nonsense.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsGonnaSuck)
[Kill the God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillTheGod): It was explicitly forged by men to fell the gods.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): Sports [two](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRdBofHcGYA) [themes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ngtUeG4mRgI) during its boss fight, melodies of which call back to *Final Fantasy V*'s Omega.

[Marathon Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MarathonBoss): Its massive resistances and extremely high damage output means you'll alternate between dealing scratch damage and frantically healing/reviving your party, leading to a grueling fight that lasts half an hour and upwards. The fight can be significantly shortened if you apply the right critical buffs before the battle, however.

[Mechanical Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalMonster): It's a mighty warmech created to slay gods, and sure as hell lives up to a superboss's endurance. The technology behind it is so powerful that Niflheim sought to salvage some of its components, namely its cannon design, which also appears on the Empire's warships. Thankfully, only one is fought.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Its appearance is modeled after its *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV)* incarnation.
[Nigh-Invulnerable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerable): It's heavily resistant to everything *except* the Royal Arms.

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): Like all of its previous iterations, Omega's body is charred black with crimson wires coursing through its legs, and glowing red optics on its head, cannon and angler-like appendage. It's described as a weapon that knows no compassion, only destruction.

[Shrouded in Myth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShroudedInMyth): Ignis recounts that he read about such a weapon being created in antiquity, but initially dismissed them as mere myths since the thing is so ancient. Nobody expected Omega to appear in the present day, aeons after its creators expired.
[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): You really have to stray off the main story's path to encounter it, and it's predictably one of the toughest and longest boss fights in the game.
[Teleport Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeleportSpam): It's introduced as warping out of nowhere to fight your party, and it even teleports around the field during its battle.

tropeName: There Is No Kill Like Overkill
tropeNotes: [There Is No Kill Like Overkill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThereIsNoKillLikeOverkill): Its first response to any attack is to *immediately* prepare Wave Cannon.

[Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed): Knocking off half of Omega's health will make it occasionally go on a frenzied state where its movements are considerably accelerated and is more aggressive for a short time, after which it overheats and has to blow off some steam, leaving it momentarily vulnerable before it teleports to a safe location to resume its assault.

[Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun): The main cannon on its "chin" is capable of firing a massive blue stream of energy, after which Omega is left immobile as it blows off exhaust.

[Innocent Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentAliens): The very definition of it. They are downright child-like in their innocence and friendliness, and much the same, are incapable of any kind of violence. It's why they are helpless against the Eroder.
[Nice Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Even when they're being mischievous, they are quick to apologize when Sarah scolds them.
[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): They can't fight themselves, which is why they needed to summon a great hero. Luckily, they got two for the price of one!
[Rule of Cute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfCute): Why do they look the way they do? Because it's cute! Plus they're Hiso Aliens.
[Series Mascot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriesMascot): They're the mascot characters for both *Mistwalker* as well as the *[Terra Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TerraBattle)* games.
[Adorable Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdorableAbomination): Its initial appearance is that of an angry-looking Hiso Alien, cuteness and all.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): This thing is completely and utterly *insane*. After taking on Sarah's appearance, it spends a good chunk of the fight boasting and ranting about its power or laughing maniacally.
[A God Am I](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI): It outright declares itself a god after copying Sarah's powers and abilities.

[Black Eyes of Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfCrazy): After it takes Sarah's appearance, its eyes turn a crazed black. Hell, even as a Hiso Alien it had these on the account of it looking *meaner* than the average Hiso Alien.

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): It primarily uses darkness and gravity-based attacks, usually in the form of [Energy Balls](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyBall) that will draw Sarah and Noctis in and deal damage.

[Computer Virus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComputerVirus): It is this from the Hiso Aliens' perspective. The Hiso Aliens have been trying to build their world, then this thing shows up and begins erasing it. During the fight with Sarah and Noctis, it outright threatens to delete them. It even plays with the idea visually, with its most noticeable feature being the red glitchy aura surrounding it, glitches that are also seen around the area you fight it in.
[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): After it assumes Sarah's appearance and personality, it uses her skillset imbued with darkness-based energy attacks.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): The most straightforward example in the game. It is a being of unknown origins, has no defined shape, is immensely powerful, doesn't act even remotely human, and its presence has a negative effect on the environment around it.
[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): There's really nothing much to it other than wanting to kill and destroy everything.

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): It can summon up to three [Living Shadows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingShadow) to fight alongside it. They can be destroyed, but it can summon them as fast as you destroy them. In the fight's second phase, it absorbs them for another boost in power.

[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): After it takes Sarah's appearance, it gains several levels of Ham. [Ashly Burch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/AshlyBurch) clearly enjoyed [Chewing the Scenery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChewingTheScenery).
[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): It is *very* fast in combat and has some powerful attacks. Even as a Hiso Alien, it's alarmingly quick.

[Ominous Visual Glitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousVisualGlitch): After taking Sarah's appearance, its most noticeable feature is the red glitchy aura surrounding it. Also, its presence causes this effect to the environment around it.
[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): It desires nothing less than total destruction.

[Only Known by Their Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyKnownByTheirNickname): The Hiso Aliens call it "The Eroder" as it is literally eroding their world. As it never referrs to itself as The Eroder, its unknown if that's its name or if it even *has* an actual name.

[Power High](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerHigh): After taking Sarah's appearance and powers, it spends a good chunk of the fight ranting and boasting about its new powers. And it only gets worse when it absorbs its living shadows to further increase its power.

[Shapeshifting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Shapeshifting): It's primarily a shapeshifter, taking on the appearance and powers of anyone it comes into contact with. It takes on Sarah's shape after she pushes Noctis out of the way and had she not done so, it would've turned into a dark version of Noctis with all his powers.
[Spellblade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Spellblade): Like Sarah, it can infuse its sword with energy for powerful, long-ranged slashes.

[Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed): Taken literally, after reducing it to half health, it absorbs its shadows to gain another power boost, turning the area around it red. During this phase, it will now use all the dark energy attacks used by its shadows.

tropeName: You Cannot Grasp the True Form
tropeNotes: [You Cannot Grasp the True Form](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCannotGraspTheTrueForm): We never get to see what it actually looks like. By the time Noctis and Sarah encounter it, it has taken the shape of a Hiso Alien.
[Bird People](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BirdPeople): They are avian in their appearance. They've long lost the ability to fly under their own power, but retain vestigial wings.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Much like their goddess, they have a keen mastery of wind magic.
[You No Take Candle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouNoTakeCandle): Their manner of speech is very primitive-sounding.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): In comparison to other primals, whose goals range from subjugating the wills of others to protecting their beastmen subjects, Garuda just wants to kill everyone she sees.
[Black Eyes of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfEvil): Her eyes are as black as her soul.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): As befitting a primal known as the "Lady of the Vortex", Garuda has immense mastery over wind.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Fallen Angel", her boss theme from FFXIV, is also used here during the battle against her.

[Person of Mass Destruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonOfMassDestruction): The threat she poses is greater than simply going on a killing spree: [primals require vast amounts of aether to maintain their physical form](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicEater). Left unchecked, she could drain Eos dry of its very life force.
[Power Echoes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerEchoes): Her voice has a distinct distortion effect to it, befitting her being a destructive god-like being.
[Self-Duplication](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDuplication): One ability she has is the power to create copies of herself to swarm and overwhelm her prey

[Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill): By using her [Signature Move](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignatureMove), Aerial Blast, Garuda decimated the entire party.  (SPOILER) It takes the divine intervention of the Messenger to save the day.

[Wrong Context Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongContextMagic): Outside of some daemons, purely magical beings are rare on Eos, save for the Astrals and their Messengers. Garuda is not a daemon, Astral, or Messenger; she is, in essence, a sentient mass of aetheric energy given shape by the minds of her devotees. Typically, large quantities of aether crystals are used to facilitate a primal summoning, but there are none to be found on Eos. There are Meteorshards, however...

VGDCName: The Messenger / Garuda, Emissary of the Winds
TvTName: The Messenger / Garuda, Emissary of the Winds
tropeNotes: [Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): The party was positively getting their asses handed to them by Garuda when she stepped in and dealt the final blow to the insane primal. Afterwards she becomes a new summon, fulfilling a similar gameplay mechanic.

tropeNotes: [Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): She has a great mastery of the wind, like her namesake, dropping a massive burst of wind from the clouds to flatten Noctis' enemies.

tropeNotes: [Cool Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolMask): She wears a decorative mask shaped like a bird's head, covering the top half of her head.

tropeNotes: [Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): Her summon attack, "Call of the Crosswinds", unleashes a massive downburst upon the ground from high in the clouds.

TvTName: The Messenger / Garuda, Emissary of the Winds
tropeNotes: [Psychotic Smirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoticSmirk): Downplayed. She flashes a smug grin as she lays the smackdown on her foes, but she seems to be benevolent for the most part, willingly lending Noctis her aid against the invading Primal.

[The Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGhost): Implied to be a [Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter), though the nature of Astrals and their Messengers makes it ambiguous if they even *can* die.  (SPOILER) The destruction of the crystal causes all of the gods to fade away, so Odin is not coming back.
